reviews.review: STAHP! that is enough to get the game

Very fun single-player experience with lots of variety. I like the world that's been created here and clearly there's a lot of care put into the environments and the concepts to flesh them out satisfyingly. Some of the "old game-isms" are in here (like having to figure out some of the controls on your own, having to figure out where to go, etc) but really, that's part of the charm. Very soulful game.
Not my personal favorite, but it's the best game I've ever played

Yes and No actually. Yes ONLY if you want to experience the original half life in it's goldsorce glory.

The actual review:
The game starts out great. It's a lot of fun to play and is very nice. I don't have much to comment on here aside from it being just as people told me it was. A great game.
Unfortunately past Office Complex is where I begin to have issues with the pacing, difficulty, and various other aspects. It really begins to show it's age late game. I found myself just wanting it to end. Getting stuck, unsure where to go, low on health and ammo frequently, constantly reloading a save because of one wrong move that I had no idea would kill me. The finale felt extremely rushed and boring. The final boss almost pitifully easy.

I recommend this only if you want specifically the goldsource version of half life for mods or what have you. If you just want to play half life or are new to the series. Go play Black Mesa. It's a massive improvement over this in both graphics and almost every other aspect while remaining very faithful despite having brand new additions. (I have played both of them)

Stating that this is the best video game franchise ever made is an understatement.

With that out of the way, The game is certainly very difficult (even on easy) But the actual experience throughout gives a feeling of dread.

On modern systems the game runs VERY fast, after all, It was made in 1998 but that doesn't make the game any worse.

I highly recommend this game.

Half-Life is an old game, but that doesn't mean its bad. Actually its an absolute masterpiece, I won't say the graphics are good (by todays standards they're terrible) but I didn't mind it, the gameplay and the enviromental storytelling make up for it and have room to spare. It just felt like a marvellous experience even without knowing its inmense impact in the gaming industry.

In this groundbreaking FPS, you play as Gordon Freeman, an MIT graduate with a PhD in Theoretical Physics, who is employed as a Research Associate at the Black Mesa Research Facility. He is needed for an experiment that winds up creating the worst day at work ever. You know how in the original Doom, the UAC was doing experiments involving portals from Phobos to Deimos, and they end up having demons from Hell invading? Well, something kinda similar happens here: while experimenting with with a strange crystal, Gordon finds himself accidentally initiating a "resonance cascade," which brings aliens from another dimension to Earth, wreaking havoc in the facility. After sh*t hits the fan, its up to Gordon to find a way to close the interdimensional portal, while also dealing with a special unit of the United States military sent to deal with the aliens, as well as silence all Black Mesa personnel.

As I stated before, this was a groundbreaking FPS in the late 90s. Enemy AI is more complex than its contemporaries were, and thus you need to be more careful with how you progress in the game. Set entirely in first person, there's a strong narrative focus here, with NPCs being a somewhat important way to progress the game, along with various setpieces in each level. Oh yeah, and the levels are interconnected rather than pushing a button and moving on the next level immediately. 

The atmosphere of these levels are fantastic, and the puzzles will get you thinking. The combat meanwhile, is great, due to the weapons you get to use. While some enemies are frustrating, at the very least there is a variety of them, which means things will never get to stale in that regard. The soundtrack, whenever there is music, is incredible.

Overall, a great way to start a legendary FPS franchise, and one I can recommend as just a really good game.

This is a recommendation only insofar as if you want to experience the original Half-Life, this is the version to play (as opposed to Half-Life: Source). This GoldSrc version is far less buggy/more polished than its Source engine counterpart, with the only drawback being that the flashlight is almost completely useless instead of game-breaking.

If you're thinking about getting into Half-Life as a series, though, I'd recommend starting out with Half-Life 2 instead. Half-Life, solely by way of old age, is clunky and ugly. I thought I hated Half-Life until I played Half-Life 2. Half-Life 2 makes Half-Life 1 look to Half-Life 2 the way Half-Life 2 looks to Half-Life: Alyx, if that helps.

Half-Life is a journey that's well worth going on, even nearly a quarter century after it originally launched. While the game has managed to influence countless others, it still manages to stand out on its own.

It's a good game. Even though it's 24 years old it's still better than most games today. I find I hop in the game for 20 minutes and then end up spending a couple hours playing it. It's also easy to mod. In conclusion you should buy the game.

10/10
How can I buy this game more?

The legendary Half-Life existed to me only as whispers and mentions on the bespoke wind. I had never played it or  thought I'd play it. 

Eventually I found it, bought it... and even though I have not come very far *at all*, I already find it impressive, I can understand why it's so esteemed, and I can recommend it.

In terms of FPS's, I am very inexperienced, so the best I can offer is this: Compared to the big-name FPS's I've seen clips of, Half-Life is (relatively) slow-paced. Big sustained shootouts are unlikely; this game is largely around picking and choosing where and when you shoot, rationing your munitions, and using the environment to your advantage.

In terms of story and lore-building, Half Life succeeds in an immersive way. Spoken word between fictipersons, announcements overhead, blink-and-you'll miss it sightings, big signs, visual context such as machines being present working correctly or incorrectly to various degrees, are used to make this odd sci-fi story was really happening around -and to - me.

In terms of cons, I can't think of many, largely because I have not gotten far. The most immediate that come to mind are that if you're looking for a hero, you won't find it here. The playable guy Gordon allows- and sometimes outright does- some very awful things in order to progress, by necessity. [spoiler]As an example there's a device that a scientist has cleverly perched upon to stay safe. He insists on staying there, which frankly makes sense considering the circumstances. However, that part he's perched on is conductive of lightning.

Instead of offering an option to help him off and help him find shelter somewhere else in the facility, the game requires us to intentionally reactivate the device, which will cause the scientist to be shocked to death. For me personally this was stomach-churning, which to be fair was likely the intention given the scary elements of the story and setting.[/spoiler]

There is much to discover in Half Life 1, and if anyone's interested in PC gaming history, I recommend it. Among other things it could be darn well worth it to see and even play for oneself the game that help launched Valve as we know it today - without which this platform we write and read and share and make history on and through which we can access more games than we could have ever dared imagine possible in the 90's, might not exist.
